awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Implementation Strategies and Performance of Unsaturated Bio-Cemented Dune Sand
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will explore a novel approach for dune protection using bio-cementation to stabilize and enhance natural protective structures. Dunes often present the first line of defense for the built environment during extreme wave surge and storm events. In order to remain effective, dunes must resist erosion in the face of these incidents. Understanding the physics of dune erosion is critical for devising ways to mitigate it. The research team will explore multiple treatment implementation techniques and assess their performance under extreme conditions at field-scale in a large wave flume (LWF) at Oregon State University.  Dunes will be constructed in the LWF, bio-cemented in-place, and subjected to a series of wave inundations so that their performance may be observed and quantified.  The large-scale work will be supported by coupled laboratory and numerical investigations.  The numerical investigation will provide insight into the loading conditions for which each treatment implementation alternative is preferred and the treatment design (e.g., required treatment dimensions) to have minimal impact on the natural environment while still providing the required engineering performance.  The resulting outcome of this work will provide guidance for enhancing coastal dunes with bio-cementation to prevent damage to infrastructure during extreme events.

Bio-cementation may be a viable method to mitigate dune erosion, which in turn would protect coastal infrastructure during extreme events.  We will explore two approaches to implement bio-cementation. The first implementation technique will induce bio-cementation at depth within the dune; this will result in an uncemented surficial layer which may erode but will also minimally impact the coastal habitat.  The second approach will be geared towards rapid deployment, for example, in preparation for a forecasted storm event anticipated to hit vulnerable dunes.  This rapid approach will be sprayed onto the dunes, instead of injected, since this quick application is more likely to be implemented in a rapid deployment.  Furthermore, two methods to induce bio-cementation will be explored: microbial induced carbonate precipitation (MICP) and enzyme induced carbonate precipitation (EICP). The EICP implementation will be conducted by the NSF Engineering Research Center for Bio-mediated and Bio-inspired Geotechnics (CBBG).  The research approach will include near prototype-scale experiments in the NHERI Hinsdale Wave Research Laboratory (HWRL); this is made possible by collaborating with an existing NSF project, Physics of Dune Erosion During Extreme Surge and Wave Events, which includes placing nearly 1000 tons of sand in the HWRL Large Wave Flume (LWF), the largest of its type in North America and in the top 10 in the world.  In addition to the experiments in the LWF, a complementary laboratory testing and integrated numerical modeling program are planned to assess the effects of implementation strategies with overall dune performance.  This research will advance bio-cementation technology by providing well-controlled and instrumented case studies to quantitatively compare the effect of implementation techniques on the performance of dunes. The resulting cementation patterns from the two treatment approaches are expected to be different; however, the performance of the two treatment approaches is unknown.  This approach will not only develop prototype-scale case studies of two different treatment implementations, but also provide case studies of bio-cemented sand dunes subjected to extreme storm loading conditions.  The numerical simulation approach will provide a framework to design and evaluate the stability of the bio-cementation under extreme wave loading.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
There are 7.8 million  of coastal shoreline counties in the United States with a population vulnerable to coastal hazards (Bryant et al., 2019). These coastal regions are dealing with multiple threats from more frequent and intense storms, rising sea-level, and increased flooding. Exposure of the coastal infrastructure to these hazards makes them more vulnerable and directly influences the resilience of the coastal communities. Vital resources such as energy, transportation, communication, and other essential infrastructures are threatened now by climate change-induced sea-level rise within an erosion-susceptible region.

Coastal dunes constitute a protective element along coastlines to protect the inland area from the consequences of severe storms. Over time, coastal dunes may be impacted by extreme storm events. Due to climate change and increasing storm frequency, the erosion rate exceeds the growth rate of dunes, leading to the retreat of these natural protective barriers.

Conventional methods of coastal management, such as walls and levees, are increasingly seen as less desirable in the face of the combined influences of the development of coastal communities, and the increasing incidence and severity of storms. Sustainable solutions are required to reduce the effects of extreme events on the morphology of coastal dunes and, therefore, on the coastal communities that are exposed to these hazards (Temmerman et al., 2013). Engineering with nature through the use of natural and nature-based features (NNBF) is a novel notion for coastal protection that produces economic and environmental benefits. NNBF include vegetated dunes, salt marshes, mangroves, and natural and artificial reefs.

This project focused on the use of microbially-induced calcite precipitation (MICP or “bio-cementation”) to stabilize coastal dunes against erosion. The work involved physical modeling of near-prototype-scale sand dunes at Oregon State University’s O.H. Hinsdale Wave Research Laboratory (HWRL), benchtop laboratory testing, and computer simulations.

At the HWRL, dunes were subjected to discretized storms consisting of 25 individual wave trials, each containing 300 irregular waves. Water level, wave height, and wave period were matched to the scaled Hurricane Sandy. Remote sensing technology was used to capture the evolution of the dune profile between wave trials. The remote sensing outputs confirm that the heavily cemented dune provides acceptable performance in resisting erosion during wave action. As waves collided with the cemented crust, maximum erosion occurred at the toe. The exposed crust at the toe dissipates the wave energy, and the high critical shear stress of the heavily treated surface caused the treated zone to remain intact through 22 trials. The moderately treated dune shows more erosion vulnerability than the heavily treated dune. Specifically, substantial fragmentation of the treated zone occurred in the moderately treated dune.

To provide insight into the effect of bio-cementation on shear stress improvement of treated dunes, element-scale laboratory experiments were conducted on cores taken from the surface crust after the storm simulation. The first series of tests examined shear strength improvement through bio-cementation using a conventional compression stress path. In the second set of the tests, treated and untreated sand instability was investigated using the constant shear drained (CSD) stress path.

Test results show that cementation level influenced the specimens' response to monotonic loading. The heavily cemented specimens exhibited higher strength and stiffness at small strains compared to moderately treated or untreated specimens. The CSD results show that density significantly affects the onset of instability in untreated sand. For loose and dense specimens, instability occurred at stress ratios less than and greater than critical state, respectively. The results indicate that the cementation level is connected to the slope of the instability line. Heavily treated specimens demonstrate greater resistance to collapse and a steeper instability line than the moderately or untreated specimens. At a given confining pressure, the stress ratio at the collapse in heavily treated specimens exhibited a unique value regardless of the deviator stress level.

Lastly, a two-dimensional fully-coupled hydromechanical model was developed and used to numerically simulate sand profiles subjected to repeated wave loading to investigate the wave-induced pore pressure regime in the soil. The buildup of wave-induced pore water pressure in sandy soil can lead to localized regions of liquefaction, ease soil particles to detach and facilitate erosion. The developed model can predict both components (oscillatory and residual) of wave-induced excess pore water pressure. These components can cause momentary and residual liquefaction, respectively. Of particular note, the model is capable of accounting for the effects of bio-cementation through the use of laboratory-measured constitutive parameters.

Model simulations show that soil and pore fluid properties, such as soil permeability and compressibility, influence phase lag and pore pressure attenuation. As a result of shear strength improvement and an increase in soil cyclic resistance, the rate of pore pressure generation in the treated layer was significantly lower than that in untreated soil. It resulted in negligible pore pressure generation due to cyclic shear stress.


Last Modified: 09/06/2024
Modified by: T Matthew Evans
